description.value: (4.4miles, 1 1/2 hours) Circle Line Terminal at W. 42nd St. & Hudson Greenway/Bathrooms

properties.name: Caution--Shared Pathway
properties.description: Shared bike/pedestrian path on Cherry walk from 103th St. to St. Clair Pl.  Please keep to the LEFT (the water side) of the lane divider. Do not walk more than 2 abreast.

properties.name: Restrooms
properties.description: Restroom in Whitehall Ferry Terminal on 2nd floor.  Go up escalator and through free turnstiles,  Restrooms to your left

description.value: This Greece inspired rest stop with its Doric columns was built in 1925 by the Parks Department.  It was formally a two story structure with public restrooms below.

properties.name: Restrooms
properties.description: Restrooms located in Target on second floor

properties.name: Restroom
properties.description: This is a one person restroom.  Cross the FDR Drive to reach it.

description.value:
• Avoid blockages due to construction on the walkway by taking the pedestrian
bridge at E. 78th St. Walk out to York Ave., TURN LEFT (south) on York Ave. and
Sutton Place to E. 53rd St.
• At E. 53rd St., BEAR RIGHT and walk to 1st Ave.

Little Island

A.  TURN RIGHT on 135th St. to 12th Ave.

B. TURN LEFT (north) onto 12th Ave.

C. Take the path that zigzags to 138th St.

D. TURN Left on 138th st. to enter the park

E.  TURN RIGHT and enter Riverbank State Park at 138th St. then exit the park via the stairs at the north end of the park..

F.  Continue north on the Hudson River Greenway.

properties.name: START/FINISH
properties.description: Fraunces Tavern Address: 54 Pearl St, New York, NY 10004

description.value:
1. Exit Inwood Hill Park at Isham St. to 10th Ave.

2. TURN RIGHT on 10th Ave. to Harlem River Drive.

3. BEAR LEFT onto the Harlem River Drive
Greenway.

properties.name: Restroom
properties.description: Go down stairs.  Restroom located in building.

description.value:
Greenway may be closed from approximately 5/4/2022 for 4 months.
1. Take the 181st Street Pedestrian Bridge over the highway making an immediate right onto Riverside Dr.  Walk one block to 181st. street. 

2. TURN LEFT at 181st street to Broadway. 

3. TURN LEFT on Broadway to Dyckman St. 

3. TURN LEFT on Dyckman street and proceed to the Greenway entering Inwood Hill Park.

properties.name: Detour
properties.description: There may be a detour on the walkway at E. 68th St., if so, exit the walkway at the E. 71st St. pedestrian bridge, walk out to York Ave., go left (south) and walk to E. 53rd St.

properties.name: Fraunces Tavern To Inwood Hill Park

description.value:
1. Begin the Great Saunter by crossing Water Street, at the back of Fraunces Tavern, turn right and walk past the Staten Island Ferry Terminal, turn left into Battery Park just past the big playground.

2. Walk straight out to New York Harbor, turn right, and walk past Castle Clinton and Pier A to Battery Place.

3. Continue north along the Hudson River passing Little Island Park (mile 4), Chelsea Piers, Circle Line (42nd St.), Riverbank State Park (mile 12), Little Red Lighthouse and the George Washington Bridge (mile 12), the Grecian Temple (mile 13).4.

4.Enter Inwood Hill Park, at Dyckman St.

1. A long switchback ramp at the end of the walkway will lead down to Dyckman St.
Cross Dyckman St. and enter Inwood Hill Park.

2. Take the pedestrian bridge over the tracks. KEEP LEFT at each fork, pass beneath the Henry Hudson Bridge, continue down the hill.

3. At the bottom of the hill take a short left past Shorakkopoch Rock, go right directly after the rock, then take the next right to go up the hill behind the dog run and toward the flagpole.

4. Just beyond the flagpole is the Great Saunter lunch stop.

1. Follow the ramp away from the river to 155th St.

2. BEAR LEFT onto Edgecombe Avenue and walk to 145th St.

3. TURN LEFT on 145th St. (east) to Malcolm X Blvd. (Lenox Avenue).

4. TURN RIGHT (south) onto Malcolm X Blvd. 

5. Take Malcolm X Blvd to 143rd St. 

6. TURN LEFT on 143rd St.

1. Just past 142nd St., enter the pedestrian bridge on the left and cross the Harlem River Drive to Harlem River Park.                                   

2. Walk south through the park with the Harlem River on your left.

3. Follow the path as it makes a U-turn on to the highway ramp and out to Madison Avenue at East 135th St.

1. Walk on 135th St. to Madison Ave.

2. TURN LEFT (south) onto Madison Ave. to 128th St.

3. TURN LEFT (east) onto 128th St. to 2nd Ave.

4. TURN RIGHT (south) onto 2nd Ave. to 120th St.

5. TURN LEFT (east) onto 120th St. to Pleasant Ave.

6.  RIGHT (south) on to Pleasant Ave. At the end of Pleasant Ave. enter Thomas Jefferson Park.
Follow the park walkway to the pedestrian bridge at E.112th St. 

7. Cross over the FDR Dr., At  the end of the pedestrian bridge walk south with the Harlem River on your left.

8. ENTER CARL SCHURZ PARK at E. 88th St. for an afternoon break.

properties.name: Carl Schurz Park to East River Esplanade

description.value:
1. CONTINUE SOUTH on the Esplanade past the red Alice Aycock Pavilion, then left on York Ave. and Sutton Place to E. 53rd St.

3. BEAR RIGHT (west) on to E. 53rd St. and walk to 1st Ave.

4. TURN LEFT (south) on 1st Ave to E. 37th St.

5. TURN LEFT (east) on to E. 37th St., proceed through the tunnel beneath FDR Dr. to the East River Esplanade.

properties.name: East River Esplanade to Fraunces Tavern

description.value:
1. TURN RIGHT (south) on the East River Esplanade to Old Slip.

2.  TURN RIGHT on Old Slip to Pearl St.

3. TURN LEFT (south) on to Pearl St. and continue to FRAUNCES TAVERN.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/5RSCCrHs1PU

31 miles, 10 hours.    John Robling's dream of spanning the East River had to overcome corrupt politicians, (sell bonds and charge a toll to bypass the local politicians), greedy contractors substituting inferior material (design the bridge 6X's stronger than needed), industrial accidents of fires, falls, the bends, he gave orders through his wife who self-trained as an engineer and his son Washington who completed the project).
To much fanfare the bridge opened on May 24, 1883.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/UpzdU0noJ7M

Video: High Bridge Water Tower 

Now listed on the National Register of Historic Places the High Bridge Water Tower, part of the Old Croton Reservoir system was built to provide water to people living at a higher elevation than the Old Croton Reservoir could provide. Water was pumped into a holding tank and then flowed out to provide water to the surrounding area.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/VA0hwmz3yjg

(3.2miles, 1 hour)  IAC Building also known as the Frank Gehry building, is Mr. Gehry’s first building in NYC. As stated in the New York Times:
“with its billowing sheets of curved glass that evoke the sails of a clipper ship, its partly white windows, and the world’s largest high-def screen in its stark, expansive lobby, it’s unlike anything in Manhattan.”

Picture: IAC Building (http://www.flickr.com/photos/59190339@N05/8407247092/in/photostream/)

16 miles, 5 hours)                                                   Video: Sputin Duyvil, just for fun video (http://www.voicesofny.org/2012/04/video-finish-the-cliffs-of-the-bronx/)
"Inwood Hill Park... (is) the second largest park in Manhattan, it is also the last expanse of naturally seeded forest left on the island. Inwood Hill Park holds varied terrain supporting birds, racoons, wild cats, and waterfowl...around its enclosed lagoons...the only saltwater lagoon left in Manhattan." Excerpt from Cy A Adler's Walking Manhattan's Rim: The Great Saunter (Green Eagle Press) p. 74.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZzBRpwW_Mks

9.5 miles, 3 hours) Built atop a city wastewater treatment facility, Riverbank State Park (affectionately known as Park El Stinko by the local residents) has many amenities including ballfields, bathrooms, pool, skating rink, and a restaurant. Its promenade offers views of the Palisades and George Wahington Bridge

https://www.youtube.com/embed/WT8RwJLg_wY

From the plaque:
"This 50-foot-tall, gray gneiss, Gothic-style lighthouse was built in 1872. It is not an official Coast Guard lighthouse, but it was commissioned by the city. The lighthouse’s purpose was to “effectually light” the nearby New York City Insane Asylum for boats navigating the treacherous Hell Gate waters. It was designed by architect James Renwick, Jr., whose other works include Smallpox Hospital and St. Patrick’s Cathedral. Inmate labor was probably used in the city-run project, but to elaborate much on its construction is to explore legend."
Secretariat Building of UN..  Museum of Modern Art Video about the facade:  https://www.moma.org/collection/works/195069.

Alfred Pancoast Boller is NYC’s unsung bridge builder. Boller designed the Madison Avenue, 145th Street, University Heights and Macombs Dam swing spans over the Harlem, and when you view them, they are all of the same swing bridge template — all versions of the same bridge. This isn’t a bad thing, since in Boller’s era, attractiveness in bridges and public works ranked equally to their usefulness. (From Forgotten New York: University Heights Harlem River Gem).
https://www.youtube.com/embed/TpanBnZ0-lw

https://www.youtube.com/embed/Wr9DCuw1FD8

Video: Willis Ave. Bridge Project

https://www.youtube.com/embed/2xONxTDy378

11.4miles, 4 hours                                                      
"The steel tubular Little Red Lighthouse built in 1880 originally stood at Sandy Hook, New Jersey. In 1921 the U.S. Coast Guard moved it to Jeffrey's Hook to prevent the extensive Hudson River shipping traffic from piling up on the rocks near the coast. But the George Washington Bridge, opened in 1932, rendered the little lighthouse obsolete....But when the hard-nosed Coast Guard auditors decided to demolish it in 1942, a considerable public outcry ensued, due to the popularity of Hildegarde Hoyt Swift's children's book, The Little Red Lighthouse, and The Great Gray Bridge (Harcourt Brace). New York City Parks Commissioner Robert Moses was persuaded to transfer the lighthouse to city ownership in 1951." Excerpt from Cy A Adler's Walking Manhattan's Rim: The Great Saunter, (Green Eagle Press) pp. 62-63.

https://www.youtube.com/embed/uCOkLi7S7qM

High Bridge

"Carl Schurz Park is named after the famous reformer who immigrated from Germany in 1852 and went on to become a United States senator and editor of The Nation and The New York Evening Post....(Home) to the Mayor's residence...Gracie Mansion, located on the northern triangular end of Carl Schurz Park, was erected in 1799 by Archibald Gracie as a summer home for his family. The city acquired the mansion in 1923, and it has been the official residence of the New York City mayors since 1942." Excerpt from Cy A Adler's Walking Manhattan's Rim: The Great Saunter pp.104-105 (Green Eagle Press).
